questionListItems.title: Can I apply for nursing home placement for my father/mother?

answer.body:
To apply for subsidised nursing home placement, the care recipient must meet all the following criteria:

  • Be physically or mentally disabled because of illness;

  • Semi-mobile, using a wheelchair or is bedbound, and needs daily care and help with activities like going to the toilet or walking; and

  • Unable to be cared for at home by family or Migrant Domestic Helper, and

  • Exhausted all other community care options such as Day Care, Home Care services etc.

  • Meet the means-test criteria for MOH Residential Long-Term Care services.

Please click here for more information about Nursing Homes.

questionListItems.title: How do I get admission to a Nursing Home?

answer.body:
If your loved one meets all the eligibility criteria for a nursing home, you may approach the Medical Social Work Department at the hospital/ polyclinic where your loved one is receiving treatment or goes for medical appointments at. The Medical Social Worker (MSW) will assess him/her and if found eligible, the MSW will assist to put up an application to the Agency for Integrated Care (AIC) for him/her.


Please click here for more information about Nursing Homes.

questionListItems.title: How can I apply for Nursing Home subsidies?

answer.body:
The subsidy level for nursing home will depend on the Household Means-Testing.


The basic cost varies between $2,000 and $3,600 a month to stay in a nursing home (before MOH subsidy), depending on the level of care required. Additional charges include one-time refundable deposit and administrative charges. Other charges which are not covered by the basic cost may apply.


You can click here for more information on the MOH subsidies for government-funded Intermediate Long-Term Care (ILTC) services.

Respite care provides temporary relieve for caregivers who are facing daily challenges caring for seniors.

Please click on the types of respite care available for more information:

topics.title: General information on Agency for Integrated Care

questionListItems.title: What is Nursing Home Respite Care (NHRC)?

answer.body:
The Nursing Home Respite Care (NHRC) service offers subsidized nursing home respite care which gives the caregiver temporary reliefs while their loved ones is cared for in a nursing home. This service can also help families that rely on Migrant domestic workers caring for a care recipient when the worker takes leave to go back to her home country. The minimum period per stay is 7 days. Eligible caregivers could receive a maximum of up to 30 days subsidized nursing home respite care per calendar year (including admission and discharge date).


Please click here for more information on the Nursing Home Respite Care service.

questionListItems.title: What service does Nursing Home Respite Care (NHRC) provide?

answer.body:
The nursing home respite care (NHRC) provides the following service:

Nursing Care

Such as assistance with care and maintenance of Nasogastric Tube Feeding, Wound Dressing, Stoma Care, Urine Catheter, etc.

Help With Activities Of Daily Living

Such as feeding, dressing, showering, toileting, transferring and/or mobility.


Please click here for more information on the Nursing Home Respite Care service.

questionListItems.title: What are the eligibility criteria for Nursing Home Respite Care (NHRC)?

answer.body:
To apply for the Nursing Home Respite Care (NHRC) service, the Care Recipient must meet the following conditions

He/She must be a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident (PR),


Has passed the household means testing (HHMT) for intermediate and long-term care subsidies and must be able to co-pay for the service required,


Has moderate to high nursing care needs (e.g. is semi-mobile, wheelchair-bound or bed-bound, needs daily nursing care and/or help in personal care such as feeding, toileting and transferring, has physical or mental disabilities because of medical conditions such as stroke, dementia and other chronic diseases),

Applying due to the one of the following reasons such as:

  • Primary Caregiver requires medical treatment

  • Disruptions in physical living arrangements (e.g. renovations, home upgrading),

  • Migrant Domestic Worker (FDW) is going on home leave and/or

  • Caregiver requires a break from prolonged caregiving.

There must be a discharge care plan for the care recipient after the period of respite care.

Please click here for more information on the Nursing Home Respite Care service.

questionListItems.title: How do I apply for Nursing Home Respite Care (NHRC)?

answer.body:
To apply for this service, your loved one must meet the following minimum criteria:

1. Has moderate to high nursing care needs;

2. Has a long-term care arrangement in place.


There must be a discharge care plan for your loved one at the end of the respite care period.


You may approach a Care Consultant at your nearest AIC Link, or contact any private nursing home for assistance. All applications for subsidised respite care are to be submitted 4 weeks prior to the requested admission date. This is to provide sufficient time for AIC to process your application and for the nursing home to review and conduct the necessary assessments.


Please note that application does not guarantee placement – this is subject to the nursing home's assessment and their bed availability during the intended respite period.


Click here for more information on government subsidies.


Documents Required for Nursing Home Respite Care applications


Please prepare the following documents to facilitate the nursing home's review of your application:


A copy of the Care Recipient's Medical Report, including his/her chest X-ray result. Please note that the report should be dated no earlier than six months from the intended date of admission.


These are suggested ways to obtain the Medical Report:


Use Care Recipient's hospital discharge summary if he/she was discharged not more than 6 months ago; or

Through the Care Recipient's regular General Practitioner; or through participating medical facilities like polyclinics and SATA Commhealth.


The participating medical facilities will be able to assist you with the required Medical Report and Chest X-ray within 1-2 working days.


Your doctor should include the following details in the Medical Report:


  • Diagnosis

  • Clinical history

  • Current functional status

  • Required nursing procedures

  • Drug allergy history (including list of current medications)

  • Cognitive and behavioural symptoms (if applicable)

  • Results from Chest X-Ray

Centre-based Respite Care service is provided at participating day care centres where healthcare professionals will care for your loved one for a few hours. Your loved one can be a senior or an adult with physical and/or mild cognitive needs e.g. toileting and mild dementia.


Please click here for more information on the Centre-based Respite Care service.

questionListItems.title: Which centres provide Centre-based Respite Care (CBRC)?

answer.body:
You may find the list of centres that provide Centre-based Respite Care services through the Care Services Recommender at the Support Go Where webpage.


Please click here for more information on the Centre-based Respite Care service.

questionListItems.title: What documents do I need to submit for Centre-based Respite Care (CBRC) application?

answer.body:
To apply for Centre-Based Respite Care, you will need to prepare the following documents:


A copy of your loved one's NRIC

A copy of your (the main caregiver's) NRIC

Latest medical records of your loved one, such as hospital discharge summary (if available). Ideally, the medical records should not be older than 1 year from your application to the service.



*Note: A doctor's referral is not required for the application. However, please check with the day care centre you are applying to if they require other documents.

If you need help in completing the application form, you may contact the centre for assistance.


https://www.aic.sg/care-services/day-care/Please click here for more information on the Centre-based Respite Care service.

questionListItems.title: Who will update me on the outcome of the Centre-based Respite Care (CBRC) application?

answer.body:
Upon receiving your application for Centre-Based Respite Care service, the centre will contact you to arrange for a Pre-admission Assessment with both you and your loved one at the centre. This session is to allow the centre to better understand the needs of you and your loved one. The centre will also share if there are other considerations and requirements before your loved one is enrolled into the service.


Please click here for more information on the Centre-based Respite Care service.
Shelters and community homes are for elderly people who can move about on their own, but who do not have family or caregiver to look after them. Such homes also help the elderly to stay independent.

questionListItems.title: What services do sheltered homes provide?

answer.body:
Shelters or community homes provide the following services:

  • Accommodation, Socio-recreational Activities, Meals And Laundry Services

  • Financial Assistance

  • Information And Referral Services

questionListItems.title: How can I apply sheltered home for a senior?

answer.body: To apply a sheltered home for a senior, you can approach the social worker or medical social worker from the hospital, family service centre, or polyclinic that your loved one visits.
